title: State of New York: The Future of the MTA with Chair and CEO Janno Lieber and 92NY CEO Seth Pinsky

rawLines.text: [Music]
hello and welcome to the 92nd Street y
New York series The the state of New
York where we give you a chance to get
to know the people making decisions
about New York's future we want this
series to serve as a platform for
fostering meaningful dialogue and to
introduce you to the decision makers who
are creating New York's future giving
audiences the opportunity to learn more
about what makes our city tick and the
pressing issues that shape our lives I'm
Seth Pinsky CEO of 92n and today we're
exploring a wide range of Transportation
issues with the chair and CEO of New
York's Metropolitan Transportation
Authority Jano Liber thank you to each
of you for joining us today and now
let's get started we're joined today by
chair and CEO of the MTA Jano Liber Jano
welcome good to be with you so let's
start with a framing question um I'm
curious where we are right now in terms
of the postco recovery when it comes to
the transit Network the buses the
Subways and the commuter rails I you
know Seth I think we're in great shape
um the rest of transit in the United
States is struggling a bit you know
hybrid work work from home um and all
you know people moving away to some
extent from some Urban centers has
really hurt transit in many many
communities across the country in New
York Transit has come back like Gang
Busters we're now on subway buses in
commuter rail adjusting a little bit for
the growth in in Fair evasion which is
its own challenge but we've got about
between 80 and
85% of the ridership that we had before
covid even though New York's lost a
little population and work from home is
still having some real impact uh so
we're thrilled about the return to
Transit and just this year since the
beginning of the year we're seeing
something like uh you know between 8 and
10% year-over-year growth in ridership
and paid ridership uh on each of our
services a little lower on Metro North a
little little higher on subways and Long
Island Railroad so very positive signs
and it's helped helped us to stabilize
our financial situation although as
everybody knows we got to invest in
fixing the infrastructure which has been
neglected for so long and we'll
definitely come back to that but um
before moving on to uh another topic my
understanding is that while the numbers
have come back the distribution of
ridership um in terms of times of day
times days of the week has changed
somewhat since uh the pandemic can you
talk a little bit about what you're
seeing on that front I mean I think it's
stuff that New Yorkers who uh are living
in the city uh and use the system
understand which is hybrid work is not
gone away it's still a thing it's still
a big piece of our economy so we see um
the highest ridership on mass transit
Tuesday through Thursday um Mondays have
come back um people were you know given
up on Monday but Mondays have have
really started to come back and we're
even seeing Fridays uh push uh four
million and hit four million Riders on
the subway a couple times so those are
those are signs that again normality in
terms of a five-day work week is slowly
coming back uh but what what is positive
and um really speaks to to where the
city is at is that the strongest rebound
has been nights and weekends um when
people have somewhere to go whether it's
going to theater or to visit people or
uh just out for the for the night life
um they're they are taking transit in
proportions that suggest uh you know
really good things so we get on the Long
Island Railroad on the weekends we're
over 100% on many weekends uh subways
are consistently uh in the 90 90 to 95%
range on the weekends uh so positive
signs um that when people have somewh as
I say that they want to go they're
they're they're taking Transit and
that's good for everybody so um the good
news is that ridership is coming back
we're not quite all the way to where we
were before Co but I just an important
point is we've lost some jobs we I mean
we've lost some people not jobs actually
but people and you know sometimes that
gets overlooked when people are trying
to Apples to Apples compare numbers so I
think where we are um is uh as I said
very positive Visa V uh return to use of
mass transit well that's great and it's
good that we're we're moving in a
positive direction uh one of the things
that people talk about when they talk
about the glass being more half empty
than half full and the fact that
ridership is down is that part of what
is driving Riders away from the system
especially the subway is a fear of crime
um and by some measures uh the
statistics are concerning uh the New
York Times recently ran a story talking
about how versus pre-pandemic um many
major crime categories um are up
substantially um at the same time even
more than the statistics I think the
perception of crime in the Subways
because of some high-profile incidents
that that I think all of our viewers
know about um have really uh made people
hesitant to to take um public transit at
certain times of day when you go onto a
sub platform and you see everyone
standing up against the wall which is
something that you didn't see a few
years ago um I think that's a sign of it
on the flip side I know that um in the
first quarter of this year some of uh
the statistics have indicated that crime
is now moving in a more positive
direction so I guess a question I have
for you is when you look at safety on um
our various transit systems and
especially on the subway do you think
that we're in a glass half full
situation a glass half empty situation
or how do you uh view the current
situation I I think you can't look at it
either either or you have to acknowledge
the statistics because we have we live
in a fact-based world or at least you
know I'm going to continue live in a
fact-based world no matter what's going
on at the national political level um
and and the stats are very heartening
right you we are as you said we're down
30 roughly
30% uh in felony crime in the in the sub
Subway system since uh last year year
over year uh that's a significant
positive trend you rarely get uh moves
of that scale uh in a single year and
even more significant from my standpoint
because we always look to preco we're
down 40 30 plus per Visa where we were
in the couple months right before covid
in in January February and early March
of 2020 so those are very positive signs
um the one category and and I think it
is is gotten emphasized you mentioned
that New York Times story it's true but
there's one category that has everybody
concerned about and that is what we call
felony assaults so those are uh uh
crimes where you know some hit somebody
else uh and and you know obviously it
does you know serious violence whether
it's with a a weapon or or not and those
are up um we have dug into those a fair
amount a lot of the increase is
attributable to the fact that we are
doing more enforcement in the system our
friends at the NYPD who everybody knows
they control the law enforcement in the
in the subway system um and people are
and this is a real concern people are
hauling off and hitting and attacking
the cops when they get a fair evasion
summons for example that um that has
been responsible for a growth a piece of
the growth in felony assaults and
likewise um we have reclassified attacks
on Transit workers this is something the
MTA pushed for any attack on a Transit
worker because they're public servant
you you know they're most cases
defenseless in just doing their job is
classified as a felony and therefore any
assault on a Transit worker gets uh
contributes to that growth in felony
assaults so those two categories are a a
big chunk of the increase
nevertheless there is reason to Bear
Down on why we have more felony assaults
some of it is the presence of folks who
are struggling with mental illness who
are unpredictable and who uh do bad
stuff unpredictably like hitting Transit
workers
and we have to get those people into a
better situation the Subway is no place
for somebody with serious me mental
illness uh to be unmedicated un you know
not being looked after and that's why it
is making a difference that we have uh
with both governor hokel and with
support from from the police
commissioner and a lot of cityan
initiatives is pushing to get uh more
people who qualify for
you know who really need to be indoors
uh uh what you call it involuntary
commitment or just do enough Outreach to
bring them indoors
voluntarily um and I won't get into the
stats but the MTA has been deeply
involved in making sure there are a lot
of Outreach workers es backed up by cops
in many cases so that we can deal with
this population which has impacted on
all of our public spaces in New York but
is especially um disheartening and in
some cases alarming when you're in a
closed subway car with someone who's
having a psychotic episode or on a a
platform and someone's really uh yelling
and screaming and and and obviously
struggling with mental health stuff
that's much more alarming in in in that
kind of public space where you can't
always move away as easily and so we
really do want uh those folks to get
treated the Subway is no place for them
to be housing and whether it's by
voluntary commitment or voluntarily
going as a result of Outreach efforts
that has been a priority it's starting
to make a difference and we're going to
keep pushing on that front and let let
me just pick up on on something that you
said a minute ago which is that there's
a lot about the subway and the
environment in the subway um and on the
transit system more broadly that you
don't control you have a powerful job
but you are not the state legislature
you're not the governor you're not the
police commissioner um Etc
if in a hypothetical world you could
completely control the transit
environment are there things that you
would want to see changed or that you
would do that you think would
substantially improve the experience and
the perception of Public Safety for the
Riders of the transit system well I mean
listen the number one thing is you don't
want people who are struggling with
mental health issues uh do having such a
disproportionate impact on the public
space the subway is not only a means of
transportation it's the thing that makes
New York possible so you know people can
live here and not own a car or own one
car instead of two because we have this
great mass transit system it's what
makes it possible to bring all these
people together have this Powerhouse of
an economy that we have if you make it
make people feel like I can't use that
system you are taking away you know what
makes New York possible and you're
taking away their freedom if parents
can't send a kid comfortably to school
on the subway to high school or middle
school you're taking away their school
choice if an older person can't get
around because they feel unsafe in the
mass transit system you're taking away
their ability to to really have a
comfortable retirement in New York and
so on and so on so I am a bear about
Subway safety and the perception and
experience of safety and orderliness in
the public space one of the the key
things that makes New York work and I
think that a lot of folks associated
with with uh with 92nd Street why get it
is that we all play share this public
space we're super dense nine times a
sunb belt City like Houston or Phoenix
but the reason that works is that we all
have kind of an implicit agreement we're
going to play by the same rules in the
public space because we have to share it
the same way we you know you we we share
playgrounds the same way we share
libraries the same way we share um all
these things that are so important that
bring us together and make us feel like
a community in this dense environment
and when people break rules in the
subway it's not just oh that's annoying
that person smoking where they shouldn't
be it creates a sense of disorderliness
what else would that person do if
they're willing to break all the rules
so I would actually start with you know
really making it much harder to beat the
fair and that's not just financially
it's the sense of you know for the
financial benefit to the MTA it's the
sense of order
that starts at the entrance to the the
whole system I would make
it I would have you know I would like to
make it more physical infrastructure
than police enforcement but I we intend
to change all of the subway turn Styles
which are totally outdated to the
reality of what's going on in New York
today and we need modern Fair gates in
order to stop it we need to close those
exit gates which the fire code requires
but which have become as I always say
the super high way of fair evasion and
we need um more people uh to feel like
uh as you come in that this isn't a
place which from the get-go seems like
there no rules here but it feels like
this is a shared space that everybody
respects so I I would be you know I'm
I'm not a a law enforcement maximalist
at all but I do want to create a very
safe and law-abiding environment for
everybody in in mass transit um that
that's the principal thing that I I I
would I would uh uh address um but you
know the the the mental health issues
are sort of much bigger than just Subway
it's the most you know the place you
experience it most directly or face Toof
face with our social problems um it's
something that we as a society need to
address I grew up in New York when they
were deinstitutionalizing people out of
the the big uh mental uh psychiatric
inpatient facilities all around the
state and all those people were coming
into neighborhoods there were very few
of them and they weren't having but they
were starting to be recognized as a
feature of our streets as I grew up on
on you know on the west side in the 70s
um it has burgeoned into a huge impact
on our city and we have to deal with it
so let's switch gears from one topic
over which you don't have full control
um to another topic over which you don't
have full control um and it's a topic
that you and I discussed about a year
ago I guess um when we last spoke um and
that is congestion pricing um when we
spoke last uh we were getting prepared
uh to launch congestion pricing that
launch was scheduled to be imminent um
then the governor uh decided to pause
the launch um and after the elections uh
last year uh the program was brought
back at a slightly different toll level
um the program did finally launch it was
approved by the Biden Administration um
and uh then subsequently uh the Trump
Administration has come out um strongly
opposed to uh congestion pricing as
threatened to shut it down uh I think
there was a March 21st deadline that now
has been extended by 30 days but in the
meantime we have congestion pricing so I
want to get into the dispute with
Washington but before we talk about that
I'm curious from your perspective how
you think congestion pricing has rolled
out so far I I I think it's a a a
historic success you know very rarely is
the government able to do something
which immediately has positive benefits
and everybody notices we we turned on
congestion pricing the 5th of January
and within days New Yorkers including
tons of people who had previously been
against it were recognizing the benefits
of you know a lot less congestion and a
lot fter travel speed and interestingly
not only the mass transit Riders and the
urbanists and the
environmentalists uh were loving
congestion pricing as it rolled out but
all of a sudden the drivers the people
who really do drive to uh Manhattan
Central business district um were
flipping their views as reflected in
polling data and saying we love this
this is saving us so much time
businesses which are wasting billions
according to studies um with Tradesmen
and materials and deliveries waiting in
traffic are loving saving all that time
and money and New Yorkers in general are
loving not just how much quicker it is
to get in and out of the city and there
people are saving you know anywhere from
10 to 30 minutes who are coming through
Bridges and tunnels from whether it's
New Jersey or Long Island or other parts
of the region um
but people are seeing there is a ton
less you know actually measured by all
kinds of sensors there a ton less noise
uh complaints there are a ton fewer car
crashes that result in pedestrian
injuries down north of 20% in the first
couple of months so we have safer
streets we have less congestion less
noise pollution somebody who lives next
to the uh uh Midtown Tunnel who I know a
little bit they own five restaurants
told me they had the best uh January and
February in years and they're also we've
changed their lives because they live
next to the Midtown Tunnel and and life
is so much better with less congestion
and less noise so everybody's enjoying
the benefits um and uh you know in some
ways it's a surprise about how quickly
you can improve things and that's what I
love about this is it gives us some
confidence that government can actually
do something if you are willing to take
on a big issue that is a little
complicated we did the work we rolled it
out flawlessly uh in terms of the
cameras in the back office and the
charging and the communications and all
that and it's had huge success uh from a
public from a public standpoint in every
every different fact customer base
whether they're drivers or Transit
riders or as I said uh just New Yorkers
who are interested in a better City so
so let's get into the dispute now um
with Washington
on what grounds is the Trump
Administration uh saying that they're
going to reverse the approval of
congestion pricing and what is it that
has made you and Governor hokel so
confident that in her words the cameras
are going to stay on listen the there
was an agreement reach there's a
agreement reach between the federal
government and the MTA and our our
partners city and state do that approved
approved the program the program was
approved under a specific Federal
program that's been in existence for
more than 20 years I think it it it
maybe 30 years um it's I think it
started under the first President Bush
um and under the terms of that agreement
it can't be terminated unilaterally by
the federal government that's what gives
us such confidence that we're we're in
strong position legally um the the Trump
administration's uh critique of the
program such as it is has been that
somehow uh their own us do wasn't
empowered to approve it or that it
somehow doesn't comply with the terms of
the program it's not totally clear uh
what they're talking about um but the
terms of the of the federal what they
call the value pricing program uh have
been we're very clear that you the
federal government can't unilaterally
terminate an approval so that's really
what's uh what what separating us but
you know the downside for the feds I'm
not sure they recognize it or care about
it is if you pull away approvals um
randomly from programs that have in
effect for some time you may be putting
at risk programs like toll roads in uh
Florida and Texas which were approved
under the same Federal power
um that Bond holders are relying on
those approvals when they purchase the
bonds secured by the the toll roads uh
revenues in Texas and Florida they may
be doing harm to the bond market and the
ability to produce new roads in ways
that are very popular in some red States
so uh we'll have to see if that matters
to them or not but in the meantime um we
we went into federal court right away
asking the judge who's been active
dealing with all the congestion pricing
litigation in the southern district of
New York to also rule on the what we
think is the invalidity of the
administration's attempt to terminate
the program do you think that there is a
deal that could be struck with the Trump
Administration where ultimately both
sides could pull back from the brink and
save congestion pricing and allow the
administration to declare some version
of Victory I you know it's probably not
for me to uh comment on on a
hypothetical like that right now we're
in the legal process but as we as you
point out the cameras are still running
the program's still in effect we're
still you know getting all the benefits
of congestion pricing which have you
know been growing even um as time goes
on um and we'll see what happens
obviously any discussion with the Trump
Administration about where we go from
here is going mostly through governor
hokel who herself has
um uh created a dialogue with the
president uh about a number of things
and this is on that agenda as well so
that'll be um those discussions are
really hers to carry on and uh we'll
we'll we'll support her as it unfolds I
want to just ask one more question about
congestion pricing um I remember when I
served in city government um we had a
dispute with the state over a program I
don't even remember what the program was
but it was a program where the state was
supposed to give us money and they were
saying that we um weren't entitled to
the money and I was pretty confident
that if we took the state to court that
we would in fact be able to secure the
funding and I remember uh one of the
political advisers to Mayor Bloomberg at
the time um who was advising me said you
know this is a fight that you can't win
because even if you win in this
particular case the state has so many
other levers has so much uh leverage
there's so many other Pockets that they
can pick so to speak from the city that
even if you win you're not going to win
um and when I look at the fight over
congestion pricing I I think about all
the other sources of federal funding um
across the state and and even um that
the MTA is expecting do you think that
ultimately this is a fight that the MTA
and the state can win with the the Trump
Administration the fight over congestion
pricing our hope is that um as they
process the reality that there are a lot
of folks who maybe were opposed to
congestion pricing before but who are
now thrilled and and asking it to be
kept on um if that as they deal with
both the reality of the benefits and
also the way that public opinion has
shifted pretty dramatically um that they
will their views will evolve over time
um we're we we're in a very you know
tumultuous period and then early in the
presidency there no secret there's a ton
of breakage going on in Washington um
whatever you think of the substance it
it is a period of massive change um I I
think that there is there is I always
believe that you know over time facts do
matter and uh certainly political
opinions matter and I think we've got
both those on our side um and that for
those reasons I am pretty comfortable
that we we we can and will prevail the
bigger question of how the state of New
York deals with what's coming out of
Washington is really much bigger than
congestion pricing I mean it goes to the
fundamentals of the federal government's
historic support for basic uh Human
Services like Medicaid um or Social
Security which seem to be all of a
sudden uh whether you I don't know if I
describe as on The Chopping Block but
certainly in a in a period of tumultuous
change where um folks are seeing a lot
of risk and there's a lot of growing
anxiety I think those issues are likely
to be uh dealt with uh you know
separately from congestion pricing
because they have such huge National and
political implications so I don't I I
don't see congestion pricing the tail
wagging the dog of of Medicaid education
and Social Security so um one of the
purposes of congestion pricing in
addition to reducing traffic is to
generate revenue for the MTA and to help
to pay for the mta's last Capital plan
um you've put forward uh a new capital
plan uh which is a $68 billion plan um I
want to talk a little bit about that
plan um and if we could start with uh
this question what is it that you are
hoping to do with the $68 billion that
you're looking to raise and I want to
ask corollary question which is that um
I understand that you actually believe
that the MTA needs more than $68 billion
do why did you ultimately go out with a
$68 billion Capital request well I mean
look here's the bottom line is that and
there are a lot of folks who will watch
this who been around long enough to to
know that um um for maybe the first 75
years of the Subway's existence
um there was not a lot of investment
made in its physical
infrastructure and that's why um
starting in the early 80s when Dick
ravit be you know began the first MTA
Capital program there was the system was
literally falling apart the subway
system that I grew up riding in the
1970s um uh the IRT as uh as we called
it still then
um uh was you know literally on the
verge the trains broke down every 5,000
miles there were derailments you never
got off the ex the local in the hopes
that the express would come because the
chances that another train would come
anytime soon were pretty uncertain uh
there were significant Investments made
we fixed the track the track so the
trains didn't fall off the tracks every
five minutes we got new rail cars so
instead of breaking down every 5,000
miles uh our train uh frequency of
breakdowns went up by you know 40 30 not
40 times but uh 25 to 30 times that's
for the good but there is a ton of stuff
that my predecessors never got to and
it's just continued to get older and
break down more and more frequently the
Power Systems they're underground
they're not sexy nobody sees them but
they're starting to blow up because
nobody's invested in them and we have
literally hundreds of power substations
that are in poor or marginal condition
um that are on the verge and that could
actually cause us to lose power and have
people stuck in tunnels and trains the
structure itself both the elevated
structures that um exists especially in
the Burrows but also the tunnels
themselves have been subjected to wa to
water salt and chemicals for 100 plus
years and nobody has really made the
Investments to make sure they work the
signals in in most cases in our system
the train signals are are from the era
of Franklin delanor Roosevelt some of
them from Teddy Roosevelt it's bizarre
we have to update it it's if we don't we
we're playing Russian roulette with this
system so I have made the case and the
MTA has for the first time went out and
looked at the entire system physically
we looked at six million components and
assets and did a a huge report which
used to be done you know go in the back
room and write it up in a in in a week
not based on analysis but we went out
and did all this analysis turned it into
a huge report it's called our 20-year
needs assessment and it's fact-based and
it shows that we are a tremendous risk
if we don't invest in this very unsexy
but basic core infrastructure of the
subway system but also of of some of the
commuter rail systems and even of the
bus system as well so we came up with a
program which as you say is $68 billion
over five years that is actually less of
an increase over than inflation over our
current 5-year program which is $55
billion so we're go we think we're going
in pretty low um you're right we went
and asked JP Morgan Chase to look at um
how much would need to be invested
compare us to say a freight railroad or
an industrial operation like ConEd to
see if we could what it would take to
get us up to a state of good repair and
they said you need probably 20 plus
billion a year which would be an over
hundred billion dollar program we
brought this down not because we're
we're we're randomly lowballing but what
we said is we can only get so much money
but let's make sure that the end of this
five-year program we are we are moving
away in every category from moving
towards the Cliff of system breaking
down more and more and more as time goes
on that we're making our the system
better and more secure so we have we
won't have solved the whole problem to
bring the system into state of good
repair but we will have made significant
progress the benefit the the things that
customers will see that matter to
customers and this is important Seth
that unsexy stuff that determines
whether the train really is able to run
on time and not break down and stick
people with long delays in the tunnel
you know as as New Yorkers have usually
experienced being able to replace the
signal system means we can run more
trains safely closer together more
frequency um so there are real benefits
to New Yorkers but on top of that we're
going to continue our historic
investment in accessibility getting
elevators into all these 500 subway
stations so that every New Yorker can
use the system whether you're in a
wheelchair you have a stroller you have
a shopping cart whether you're just an
older person who's you know reached that
that stage where getting up and
downstairs ain't really an option
anymore so um there are real benefits in
terms of upgrades coming and there's one
line that we think is an important
expansion investment that we must make
which is to connect Brooklyn and Queens
there's an abandoned rail line out there
that is almost totally unutilized it
needs to be turned into a light rail
connection between Brooklyn and Queens
you shouldn't have to go through
Manhattan to get from from Brooklyn to
queens and that's what most people are
are forced to do right now and and in
terms of paying for the $68 billion so
my understanding is that $35 billion of
that is deemed to be identified although
I think 14 billion of the 35 billion is
federal funding so I don't know how uh
much the state and the MTA can count on
even that portion of the $35 billion
that's still leaves even if you assume
that that money will be there $33
billion that needs to be identified um
what do you think is the right way uh to
cover that $33 billion remaining whole
and in particular what I've heard the
governor and the legislature talking
about recently is increasing taxes which
surprised me a little bit because one of
the reasons that the governor cited for
pausing congestion pricing was concern
about the recovery of the economy
in Manhattan in particular um and saying
that there already were significant
burdens being placed on the the workers
um coming in and out of Manhattan and
that she was concerned about placing
additional burdens so now we're talking
about yet more burdens being placed on
them what do you think is the right
answer because somewhere we need to find
this $33 billion and maybe 47 billion
depending on whether the federal
government stands behind its obligations
I'll take this hopefully one at a time
number one is this assertion that it was
never realistic to view congestion
pricing as a burden on the working class
or poor people because those folks do
not drive to jobs in Midtown Manhattan
because they can't afford parking even
if they have a car overwhelmingly people
of of limited means Working Class People
or even lowincome folks uh take transit
so uh that was a bit of a shalot that
that I think over time has has
diminished and we're already seeing how
happy uh you know folks who uh are the
drivers are happy but that's because the
people who drive and pay for parking in
Manhattan do have the nine bucks uh to
uh to pay the toll listen um uh the MTA
on the question of how to fund the
capital program the MTA has historically
